resources.string: \tHaving read all the tips, you\'ll know all features of this application. \n\tNote: Turn your phone to landscape orientation. \n\tNow click on \"Forward\" button in the upper right corner to continue.

\tIn the background you see one of the pages with buttons. One of — there are lots of them! You can scroll the pages by using your finger: having closed this window, slide your finger to left or right. \n\tTry it now, not closing the dialog, using two buttons below.
\tSome buttons, as it may seem at first, mean exactly the same things. \n\tAbout these buttons on the following pages.
Orange \'Equals\' button calculates entered expression and outputs the result to input field.

Gray \'Equals\' button appends \'=\' symbol into expression. \n\nThis may be used to declare a variable or a function. To do this write into the input field, for example, \"a=5\" or \"f(x)=2x+1\" and press the orange equals button.

Used in scientific notations. For example,
\"5E3\" = \"5 × 10^3\" = 5000
and
\"2.346E-2\" = 2.346 × 10^(-2) = 0.02346.
I.e. "E" means \"…times ten raised to the power of…\".

Find out more at wikipedia.
This is Euler\'s number, approximately equal to 2.718.
A comma splits function arguments. Example: \"f(x,y)=x^y\", \"f(4.5,6)\".
A point is a decimal dot.
\tOur app uses some non-standard operators, that\'s why we put here a table of operator precedence (decreases from top to bottom).
\tLog function can take one or two arguments. \n\n\tIf only one argument is passed, then log(n) returns natural logarithm of a parameter:
\tIf two arguments are passed, then log(b, n) returns base-b logarithm of n.
\tAn example with two parameters. In what power 2 (this will be the first argument) is necessary to raise to get 8 (and this\'ll be the second)?
\tPlease note: if you can not remember the order of arguments, use a phrase from the paragraph above.

Like log, root function also can take one or two arguments. 

	By default, i.e. with a single parameter, the √ function returns a square root of the parameter. 

	If the second parameter is passed, then √(a, n) function returns a-th root of n. 
	Example:
\tOnce again, if you cannot remember the order of arguments, use the phrase: \"Take the fourth root (the first argument) of 16 (the second argument)\".
\tNaN (Not a Number) is a special value of a number. It is generated as a result of, e.g., dividing 0 by 0. Any operation (addition, subtraction, division) by NaN produce NaN.

\tUsually, when you press the button (I mean the ones in the background), exactly that character is added into the input field, that is written on the button. However, some buttons, if it isn\'t released for a time, could add the character not in lower but in the upper case. \n\tThis may be used for, let\'s say, adding a new variable, e.g. constant G in physics, not to be confused with the other variable — g (gravitational acceleration). Variable names are case sensitive! \n\tTry it here and now. Initially, simply click on the button. Then hold it down.

\t\'History\' window consists of records, each of which contains one calculation. If you click on a entry, a context menu will be open, main activities of which would be to copy or to paste expression or result into the input field. \n\tTry it now. Press on a button below. If history is currently empty, then the program will automatically add a few records.
\tBy the way, history can be accessed from the options menu that appears after clicking on three dots in the upper right corner in the background.

\tThis page is just a reminder that if you want something to change, check, whether it is possible to change in the settings. \n\tDo you need to turn off rounding, change the unit of angular measure to radians or change the period of storing the history — open the settings!

\tPages (in the background) are designed as follows: there is a home page and \"side\" pages. The home page opens immediately after the application is launched. \n\tSide pages can automatically return to home: (1) after a button is clicked, (2) do not return or (3) return after a button is double clicked. \n\tIf a side page does not return you to home, try double clicking on a button — this may help :).
